pros: This organization truly cares about its employees and the impact it has on its community! Working here has been so good for my mental and physical health. The flexibility and transparency is incredible and I feel like my working is really making a difference in the lives of the people in our community.
cons: Pay is lower than I’d like and we only get paid on a monthly basis, so finances can be tricky. However, the CEO and other leadership is extremely communicative about what they are doing to make sure their employees get the pay they need and listen to our feedback.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Bellevue, WA
pros: Team building and mission driven company
cons: Little room for growth within company.

pros: Flexible schedule, can manage your own time, great supervisor
cons: stingy compensation for travel, low pay, top management says they are open to change but when trying to advocate for a change they were very rigid

pros: Many opportunities for collaborations and supervision for those who are looking for fieldwork hours
cons: The pay is considered on the lower scale compared to other ABA companies

review_title: A wonderful, incredibly rewarding place to work at
pros:
Kindering is an excellent place to work at, particularly for therapists who are new to the field of early intervention/early support. Kindering has a very thorough onboarding program, as well as excellent mentorship that ensures everyone feels well supported in their learning. Workplace culture is great. Staff are very committed and passionate about serving children and their families, as well as friendly and encouraging of each other. There are weekly meetings where staff can collaborate and problem-solve difficult cases, as well as discuss and learn more about current best practices. Work-life balance is very manageable as long as you stay organized.
Management makes you feel heard. They meet with you regularly to check in and ensure you have space to bring up any issues or concerns you may have. Management prioritizes overall job satisfaction. They keep a close eye on caseloads to ensure staff are not overworked. They also try hard to support professional growth and career advancement by assigning staff to their desired placements and specialties.
Recently there have been pay adjustments that have put Kindering more on par with school district pay, which has historically been a concern for staff and one of the main reasons why folks left the agency. Kindering pays in full for employees’ health insurance and benefits are good, particularly if single or if the employee has children who can be on their spouse’s health insurance. Direct service providers manage their own scheduling of families, which makes the job very flexible. The early support department is also on a 44-week schedule which means there are many scheduled breaks during the year. Employees also get 11 paid holidays and 2 weeks of PTO time, which is great!
cons: Staff with children who cannot be on their spouse’s health insurance will have to pay a significant amount of money out of their paychecks to keep their children insured.

pros: Friendly, knowledgeable staff, working with families and the cutest kids.
cons: Heavy caseloads, work beyond hours, unclear communication from the exec team and never enough staff.

pros: Opportunity to work with kids if you like kids, good equipment and resources available, I believe generally the EI side had more support than the department I worked in
cons: Very little support in my department, coworkers were friendly but didn't form super close relationships (didn't hang out outside of work)

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Seattle, WA
pros: Great team environment. Ever-growing company with lots of places to lead, learn and grow as a therapist. Feel valued in my SLP department. Open to new ideas and viewpoints.
cons: Changing culture. Lots of equity problems being looked at like a lot of companies right now, but change is slow here and can be frustrating when you work with non-monolingual, white families. Lower power professionals have trouble getting their voice heard.

job_title: Special Needs Teacher in Bellevue, WA
cons: Lack of communication and unorganized team

review_title: Amazing not-for-profit dedicated to young children and their families
pros:
Kindering has a powerful mission to serve children of diverse abilities and their families by providing high quality education and therapies in a supported caring environment.  The staff are hard-working dedicated professionals who care deeply about children reaching their fullest potential, and value parents and other caregivers as key team members.  Kindering also cares about the broader community and finds ways to inform, advocate, and teach others.

Kindering has competitive wages as compared to similar organizations, offers excellent flexibility and time off, health benefits paid in full for the employee, offers a match for retirement, and has caring managers.  They have a mentoring program for new staff and a supportive environment.
cons: Kindering is always striving to do the best for children, families, and staff so there is always something exciting and new.   The most successful staff members are those who enjoy growing and learning.

review_title: Great place to learn, terrible place to stay
pros:
1. Generally helpful staff
2. Great place to learn but no specific structure
3. Dedicated to the families they serve
cons:
1. Terrible morale among experienced professionals; high turnover rate among professionals looking to grow/advance their careers.
2. Slow to support current (even past) trends in workflow efficiency. Increasing paperwork and decreasing time to do it!
3. No perks...none. We don't even get the federal rate for mileage. Forget a raise! (while upper management maintains salaries unheard of... look it up, its public data since Kindering is a non-profit)

pros: Flexible schedules that you create yourself. Amazing, knowledge team members and people who truly want to improve other families lives.
cons: Total lack of communication from the top, high caseloads, low pay, consistently work beyond paid hours, and no ability to advance within in the company. Management makes decisions without understanding the impact of those doing the work.

review_title: Organization with solid mission, employees and leadership
pros:
-surrounded by people who are passionate about the work that they do and the families they serve
-work calendar generally aligns with local district's school calendar making it more family friendly
-management is flexible and responsive to scheduling and vacation requests
cons:
-Most jobs are contracted for <46 weeks in the year, leaving weeks of mandatory unpaid "non contract hours"
-minimal opportunities for advancement

pros: collegiality, high standards and innovative strategies
cons: heavy caseload, pay in some positions not commensurate to the skill required, some entrenched ways of running the org
